About me

After graduating from the University of Notre Dame with a degree in biochemistry, I was in the rare and fortunate position of having actually made money during college and in the less-rare position of having learned little more than that I had no interest in pursuing a career in the field of my major.

I spent the next few years traveling and trying on various jobs, ranging from bartender to EMT to luthier.

In late 2011 I discovered the sport of Olympic-style weightlifting, and by early 2012 I had dedicated myself fully to the sport.

By autumn 2018, having spent a fulfilling and deeply educational seven years as a full-time athlete, it was apparent that it was time to tackle the next challenge. On a whim, I started dabbling with programming, learning a bit of javascript on Codecademy. By Christmas I was miles down the rabbit hole and certain that programming in some form was what I wanted to spend the next phase of my life doing.

Education

Self-taught programmer, web developer, and designer

Recent work

Meal Plan

Live site
Github
Concept:

To hand over to the app as much of the cognitive overhead entailed in feeding myself as possible

Design challenges:

Learning from the Training Log app, I wanted the app behave as intuitively as possible, rather than forcing the user to generate inputs that would be easy to handle programmatically.

From a pure design standpoint, creating a drag-and-drop calendar interface that was simultaneously user- and mobile-friendly was a challenge, simply because of the limited screen real estate. CSS grid with custom breakpoints and the scroll-snap API

Technical challenges:

Aside from learning two new (to me) technologies (Svelte3 and Firebase), the main technical challenge of this project was in anticipating unstructured user inputs and parsing them to something predictable. Initially, I intended to use a natural language processing library to handle this task, but I ended up preferring my own code.

A lesser technical challenge was balancing responsiveness with a desire for a single source of truth. Firestore is fast, but not instantaneous. Svelte3's stores provide a convenient way to optimistically update the UI while reading/writing to the database.

Once I was satisfied with the design for the calendar, CSS Grid and CSS Scroll Snap provided a convenient way to implement it.

Training Log

Live site
Github
Concept:

To create an app flexible and extensible enough to track any numeric training data that might be important to any athlete

Design challenges:

The concept for this project was all about letting the user specify what data they wanted to track, and then for the app to be able to sift through the data they record and look for correlations.

On the design side, this meant walking a fine line between limiting functionality and limiting fun. It turned out to be quite difficult to allow the kind of flexibility I imagined without asking the user to behave like a computer.

Technical challenges:

Training Log was my first full-stack app, and by far the biggest project I had tackled to date. I learned React, Apollo, and graphQL simultaneously for this project.

It meant a pretty draining first couple of weeks, but in the end I think it was justified. The flexibility afforded by graphQL gave me one of the things I wanted most out of this app, namely the ability to let the user define the shape of their own data, while the UI code sees predictably shaped data coming from the back end.
